Elijah Lee, Independent Financial Advisor at Phillip Securities (Jurong East Lite)Top Contributor (Sep)Level 9. God of WisdomAnswered on 06 Aug 2019To me, SSBs are an alternative to FDs, without the lock in of a FD, and with a comparable return to boot. Considering the alternative of leaving it in the bank with 0.05% interest, I would park my warchest for investing in several tranches of SSBs and liquidate them when market opportunities present themselves.0 comments3

Tee Hon EngLevel 3. WonderkidUpdated on 06 Aug 2019Transcation fee relatively cheap at $2. High liquidity. Unlikely to be defaulted. If you have DBS multiplier account, it would help to clock your investment component when you receive the interest payout.On a side note: SRS funds can be used to purchase SSB. (Not to yield the Multiplier benefits though)1 comment2

So some uses the srs amount to purchase low risk products like ssb to also gain some interest revenue. Recently the rates are on the low side for ssb though but still some prefer it as a low risk bond portfolio0 comments1
